reviewText: Take Titan's Quest, Torchlight, and M:TG and make it an MMO and you would have something very close to Mytheon.  The combat system is like no other MMO however.  Basically you collect stones (think of them as cards in a deck) and build your rotation with the stones you've collected.  There are many possibilities and a good amount of random chance which keeps combat interesting.  It's a nice change of pace to have to think on your toes in an MMO.

reviewText:
Its a great game; if you are fan of action rpg with a lot of strategy included i'm sure that you'll enjoy this game.
Of course there some stuff that need to be changed but the devs seems to be very attentive, and i'm sure they'll fix these stuff soon.

----Finally:
-Graphics: pretty good for a 2010 game... 8/10
-Gameplay: at the beginning you found yourself lost... yeah that's true but after the tutorial and read all stuff about your stones it'll be very simple to you create your own battle style... 9/10
-Music: a little bit repetitive but is good...7.5/10
-Ambient/Lore: i mean the greek stuff is pretty interesting... 10/10
-Quests: it's repetitive BUT every single map that you go, you'll need another strategy, so every map is like a new point of view about beating mobs... 9/10
-Interface: pretty simple to understand... 9.5/10
----Overall:  ≈ 9/10
And yes i played this game in the first or the second semester of 2010... it's just $4 so just buy it. Btw i recommend you guys play with friends because if you are like me it'll be like one of the Souls series.

Good luck.
Have fun.

reviewText:
This is the only game I have asked for a refund on.

The game is more suited to single player as the server was dead when I played.  Also its more of an on rails game than an mmo with freedom.  There was lag during gameplay which I saw no reason for as no one else seemed to be online.

If the game took away the need for an internet connection and launched itself as a single player game then I would recommend it but as it is I can not.  If the devs closed the server you would be left with a game you can not play.  With the lack of players Im not sure how long the devs can continue to support this game.

reviewText:
Release: Played the closed beta; the game has a very interesting gameplay mechanic that feels like deck building and RTS. Petrogylph is a company by former members of Westwood Studios. They strove to make interesting game mechanics and buying this game further supports them in their future projects. Hopefully, the more people that buy this game, newer content will be added.

2/17/15: So if you want to know more about this game, I'll give you my personal gist on it. The game design gives you an impression of a card game while at the same time a RTS. You control your hero/champion who summons monsters/structures/spells by casting stones. The story is lackluster that incorporates mythos and lore from Greek mythology. Level design is . . . meh. The game is instanced-baed like a dungeon crawler except everything is sort of revealed, which makes exploration easy because there is nothing much to explore. The quest system is purely bounty and fetch quests so far. The tutorial system is also okay; it is explored from windows and clickable books on podiums (which I think is a bad idea). I suggest ditching that mechanic and just add information that the player fetches into the same slot as Feats or Quests. Maybe implement videos in-game or establish a different tutorial system to help new players ease into the game. Someone in another review commented that the game felt clunky; I can agree wtih that except I think it's more of the engine than game. This game could use some optimizations because it should be low-spec enough that older computers can run it fluidly. The game looks graphically outdated and the closest thing that is similar is their other creation: Universe at War. Mython could use a face lift, but optimization is more important right now. The game needs more functionality. We can't bind hotkeys or openly customize the UI.

All in all, the main point of this game is to have fun and be challenged at the same time. The random chances of what castable stone appear in your slot makes the gameplay/combat interesting. The more people that buy this the more support it'll bring. I hope that we'll get like Egyptian, Viking, and Eastern Gods put into the mix.
voteText: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I played Mytheon back when it was released in the Beta format around 5-6 years ago and I loved it. Despite my horrid internet connection back then I found myself pouring hours and hours into the mythical world this game presented to me and now, 5 years down the line I was beyond ecstatic to see that the game was getting a re-release on Steam and bought it as soon as I was able.

Delving back into the game after all this time I was hit by a wave of nostalgia when I was presented with an interface I'd spent so much time interacting with all those years ago and despite the janky gameplay style, I couldn't have been happier; it was exactly how I remembered it. The stone system is a unique gameplay aspect that I've never seen replicated in any other game and it's this aspect that I think gives this game its charm.
The only real issue I have is the re-introduction of the Legacy weapons (big shiny blue ones) that used to be a badge of honour for Beta players which is now just an easily attainable pay for weapon which pretty much renders most other weapons completely irrelevant once obtained. I'm not sure what you devs are planning on doing with these weapons down the line but I hope it doesn't remain an accessible weapon for all in the future (as elitist as that makes me sound).

All in all I highly recommend this game to anyone who doesn't mind a semi-dated experience filled with nice and unique gameplay and a lore-rich world that really tickles the fancy of any Mythology head such as myself. I hope you guys in the dev office keep up the good work and polish this game into the wonder it has the potential to be.

Cheers <3

reviewText: Gameplay is much more akin to something like WoW than traditional ARPGs - i.e. a lot slower paced and enemies in general are more threatening (at least the first few areas I've played at low levels). There is not many people playing currently, which is a shame as I think this would be a lot more fun playing in a group. Worth 4 bucks easily.

reviewText:
Mytheon is a Hack and Slash MMO RPG with strategy elements set in ancient greece with evil gods and courageous heroes. You play one of these heroes and your goal is to defeat the gods.

TLDR:
- Gameplay may feel stiff/boring at first, but when playing a little longer with more challanging situations the strategy in the game comes out better. The stones collections, towers, companions and abilities certainly make a nice mix to play with. Shame there are few people though.
- graphics are okay though not impressive when global lightning is overwhelming. More moody areas look fairly nice.
- Music doesn't really draw my attention so far, but it's not bad.
= Though it's not a GREAT game it deserves more attention than that it has now. You may find this game ♥♥♥♥ and boring, but it can also be quite interesting, unique and fun to play.


There are 3 classes to choose from (I've only played the Elementalist, so I might be a little unclear about the other classes):
- Warcaster: heavy equipment, melee fighting
- Eidolon: between Warcaster and Elementalist
- Elemetalist: focuses on spells, towers and companions, quick mana regen

The basic gameplay is just to smash every monster you see and take all loot like in many other hack and slash rpg games. Leveling up simply increases your stats, nothing shiny there. What makes this game interesting (besides it's setting in greece if that interests you) is the stones you can collect. Sounds boring? Didn't catch me at first either :p. However there are stones you can collect and put in you batte set". Your battle set is a set of stones you can use during battle. For it to be usable it has to contain between 15 and 40 stones. On the bottom of the screen 6 stones are displayed. These stones are randomly picked from your battle set. You can activate them (if you aren't in a safe area) by clicking them or by pressing there corresponding number 1-6.

There are basically 3 types of stones:
- Companion: summons a companion to fight beside you. By pressing F you select all companions and by clicking on anywhere else you deselect all companions and select yourself. You can move yourself and each of you companions seperately like you do with units in an RTS. Companions disappear after a certain time and have different HPs.
- Towers: towers are the same as companions except that they can't move and often do more damage and have higher HP.
- Abilities: abilities like in any other RPG game.

You start with a basic battle set of 15 stones and can find more in loot. You can also craft stones by using ingredients or by creating them out of 2 or more other stones.

Companions can be of 3 different types:
- attacker
- defender
- ranged

these types follow Rock Paper Scissor:
- attacker GOOD AGAINST ranged
- defender GOOD AGAINST attacker
- ranged GOOD AGAINST defender

I'm not yet shure about the damage types
date:
but there are 6 listed of which 4 are elemental:
- melee
- ranged
- fire
- water
- air
- plant

water GOOD AGAINST fire
fire GOOD AGAINST air
air GOOD AGAINST plant
plant GOOD AGAINST water

All companions
hoursPlayed: and weapons can do elemental damage (not necesarily) and all can have/boost resistances.\nThis makes it important to choose the righ way to attack
voteText: because (e.g.) fire against fire does very little damage.\n\nYou can trade with NPC's (in the hub) and put items on sale for other players (or buy their items) by paying a small fee. Beside the standard coop gameplay you can play pvp 1v1 or 2v2 in an arena. Haven't tried this yet because currently there are simply to few players. There is a tutorial

votesTotal: so it's not that bad. All tutorial text can be found in the journal at any time as well.\n\nThough the music is made by Frank Klepacki it didn't really stick with me. It also seems that there are very few tracks
votesFunny: the music feels repetitive. It's not bad
commentsCount: but (so far) I didn't really draw my attention. Though it's a 2010 game the graphics didn't impress me at all at first. When you get a little further in the game and there are more lightning effects

reviewText: Played this game years ago. I'm so glad it's back! The textures are a bit dated but the gameplay is as fun as ever. The game plays like an instance-based MMO. You can party people and go in instances to fight enemies for gear and stones (ability cards). Your skills are all based on building decks of stones (abilities) that are continually regenerated at random while fighting in an instance. The random abilities keeps things interesting. There is only an online mode. You can solo if you'd like but playing with others is much more beneficial because you can stack AOE attacks.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
A nice slow Titan Quest-like Hack and Slash. Big on Greek Mythology. Should run smoothly on most systems.
Powers are linked to stones you use to summon creatures and constructs that aid your avatar.
So there is a sort of deckbuilding edge when it comes to characterbuilding.
Given the lower price well worth picking up. It's solo-able with a bit of grinding and should shine in co-op.
Given the low price and the discounts on steam, no reason not to support the return of this little game.

reviewText: While lacking polish in some areas, the game was overall a great and cheap time-sink. The gameplay is somewhat reminiscent of Diablo 2, but comes with a unique deck building system wherein you choose spells and summonables which will become available at random. Solo'ing some zones can be hard to do alone, but group is some amazing fun to make up for that. Bosses are difficult in a way that reminds me of classic wow, where your group need tailor its gear and setup accordingly. Overall game is a blast with friends and for the price would definitely recommend. What may concern some is that it does require an internet connection to play, and that in the future the game could become defunct if the servers are ever shut down. However, knowing the studio that made this game I wouldn't be surprised if when that time comes the server code is published for interested individuals to run their own.

reviewText:
It's time... time for a TOGA PARTY!!!

A good game for the Steam collection when you are in the mood to channel your inner Spartan and bring down Greek gods with your 300 power stones. You can even yell THIS IS SPARTA!!! at your screen as you play whilst taking down bosses!

The Diablo-esque controls graciously allow you to eat ambrosia with one hand whilst simultaneously playing using the other- definitely a great gameplay decision there. Also, whilst.

Mytheon gives you an inexpensive romp through the world of ancient Greece with the added bonus of beholding with your own eyes a game that has brazenly turned it's back on the zealous Freeto god of Pay.

Also, glad to see it non-FTP and microtransactioned.

PREPARE FOR GLORY!

reviewText:
This game is really awesome. I played when it was released and playing again with the new expansion...

You get stones that create towers! or cyclops or pegasus! or are spells!, and you build your 15 stones set (3 max each).
You can figure out combos pure Magic the gathering style... or you can go the easy way and just add the ones you like. Visually the game is quite satisfying...

In combat 6 random stones from your deck are available at a time. You enter a stage kick some mobs's asses and go for the bosses that give the cool loot.

There is also:
-Pvp duels
-Items, recipes, crafting...
-Market
-You can play stages in a party or solo

I really recommend it. By the way, i saw some comments on lag. I have none.
